Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> https://twitter.com/dukeleto/status/1153645872976207872

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> https://twitter.com/dukeleto/status/1153646453186805760

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> many things happening, just haven't been talking about it much

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> jl777 just made something that make Electrum look like a Betamax tape: https://twitter.com/dukeleto/status/1153683646643146754

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> nSPV = notarized Simple Payment Verification

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> HUSH has it already

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> we just need to do the work to set up the servers/etc

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> normal nodes are the "servers"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> yes. to clarify, we need to set up a few public nSPV seed nodes. I haven't done that yet

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> 1 was able to support saturation level spam from 800 superlite clients

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> that is pretty amazing

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> another awesome advantage of Hush being a KMD chain, we get amazing improvements like this from jl777

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> https://twitter.com/dukeleto/status/1153693637823336448

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> maybe the original FlyClient author will chime in

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> flyclient is much more efficient than normal headers only SPV

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> not sure the efficiency gains compared to flyclient

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> I like this model, because a Sybil attack must run full nodes, instead of some 3rd party servers. It increases the work an attacker needs to do

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and this model seems to completely remove the "malicious server that phishes you" problem, that makes Electrum unusable for the average person

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> most BTC electrum servers are malicious currently, and if older versions of Electrum connect, those clients can be phished via malicious "error messages", still to this day

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it's a sad state of affairs. It used to be BTC electrum was a reasonable and safe option

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> another aspect is that a malicious node cant give you false data, well it can, but it wont validate

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> so all that a malicious node can do is withhold data about what utxo you have

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> i guess it can also falsely report about transactions in mempool, but for large amounts if you wait for notarizations to be validated, it is like dpowconfs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> the mempool messages are more for convenience

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> the entire set of fullnodes in the network will end up supporting 800x the number of superlite clients

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> and the superlite just needs to connect to a single honest node

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> so it has the similar characteristic as PoW, where you just need one valid peer

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it's a very resilient feature of this nSPV protocol

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> DPoW is a tree that bears more fruit each succeeding year

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> yes, i never expected it could be this useful

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> like a datastructure that is non-intuitive at first, but then ends up being drastically useful in many seemingly unrelated tasks. I am constantly amazed at the unintended positive benefits of dpow

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> having addressindex and spentindex is also a critical part of the nSPV

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> without it, it wouldnt be possible, or require using explorer nodes for the listunspent data

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> ah, fascinating. All HUSH nodes enable all those indexes by default, as well

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> SilentDragon GUI wallet enables them by default in new confs, so GUI users have them by default

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> so there will be hundreds of nSPV fullnodes

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <AkiraX> What's this all mean to end user?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <actionslacks> possibly exponentially faster and more secure transactions.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <actionslacks> much greater ability to scale. also smart contracts being able to run on mobile platforms

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> nSPV allows for light (potentially mobile) wallets that only have to download a tiny fraction of the blockchain data to operate. That is what it means for end users

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> It means, no matter how large the Hush blockchain grows, light wallets will only have to download a small amount of data

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> these are "superlite" wallets. It's a more efficient algorithm than Electrum uses

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Hush has a smal blockchain right now, but when we allow file uploads, that could change. nSPV could be very important to Hush scalability in the future

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> electrum are API servers which involved polling multiple ones to get the merkleproofs you need. also it doesnt use SPV for validation, but that requires all the headers, which at 2kb per header adds up very fast

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> nSPV gets the best of both worlds. nearly as small bandwidth as API servers, nearly as secure as fullnodes

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> from start to login to spending funds can be in seconds, and that is with dpow validation

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @jl777c it is possible that a server providing nSPV services can be compensated in some way? I am thinking something like -ac_notarypay, where we bake in an incentive system for honest SPV nodes. If only a single honest nSPV node is needed for a node to get the correct data, maybe it's not important

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Another thought I had is that Electrum infrastructure heavily relies on DNS, and so DNS-based blocking is effective to stop average users. nSPV doesn't use DNS and so DNS-based censorship doesn't work

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> the load is comparable to normal p2p messages

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> if to charge for that then do we start charging for relaying blocks and transactions?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> i optimized the network bandwidth needed, so we can return just scan results of the mempool, instead of the entire mempool

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it would be an effective way to combat an extreme adversarial environment where most nSPV servers are evil, but maybe we don't need to worry about that apocalyptic world just yet

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> listunspent/listtransactions has a skipcount so you can get just the latest txid

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> nSPV seems like it's much less resource-hungry than being a notary node

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> what would an evil nSPV node do? return invalid data that is immediately detected as invalid?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> nothing like a notary node at all

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> with 800 clients spamming full blast the CPU load got to 100%
